The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.

BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts

results.json_rows_response: Adjusted EBITDA is a measure of financial performance that is calculated by combining net income and operating expenses with an adjustment for certain non-cash items such as amortization of purchased intangibles, acquisition transaction costs, and the impact of the adoption of ASC 606. ASC 606 defines non-cash items as items that are not normally included in income or loss statements, such as the impact of foreign currency exchange rates. This adjustment is not a percentage change in Adjusted EBITDA but rather a measure of the performance of a business, and is calculated by subtracting the Adjusted EBITDA for the previous year from the Adjusted EBITDA for the current year.
